New with R4.7M the NE can store a default TransferProfile containing valid xFTP access configurations
per filetype -> sheSystemFileTypeInfoTable. If this default setting should be used, no additional FTP settings
or profile information must be set together with the upload/download command.
If this default configuration is not available or not valid, the upload/download command MUST set
individual FTP access information or a valid transfer profile.
If someone uses the download command without activation then he/she may activate the profiles/loads
by resetting the corresponding hardware modules.

variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemControlTimeStamp

description: Defines the unique timestamp format for all CLI command outputs with event or status information
report, especially the 'show' commands. The unique timestamp format is supported in all
proprietary (private) logging files, PM counter files, which are not generated according any
MIB objects are be not affected by this feature!
Customer specific timestamp formats are not supported within the MIB and consequently via
A zero-length string will keep the vendor specific default implementation.
The configuration string can contain ordinary characters and conversion specifiers, identified
by a leading '%' character. Ordinary characters are copied to the output string and conversion
specifiers are replaced by values as defined below:
%d The day of the month as a decimal number (01..31).
%e The day of the month, space padded ( 1..31)
%b The abbreviated month name according to the current locale (Jan..Dec).
%B The full month name according to the current locale (January..December).
%m The month as a decimal number (01..12).
%y The year without a century as a decimal number (00..99). This is equivalent to the year modulo 100.
%Y The year as a decimal number, using the Gregorian calendar. Years before the year 1 are numbered 0, -1, and so on.
%H The hour as a decimal number, using a 24-hour clock (00..23).
%I The hour as a decimal number, using a 12-hour clock (01..12).
%k The hour as a decimal number, space padded, using a 24-hour clock hour (0..23)
%l The hour as a decimal number, space padded, using a 12-hour clock hour (1..12)
%M The minute as a decimal number (00..59).
%S The seconds as a decimal number (00..60).
%a The abbreviated weekday name according to the current locale.
%z RFC 822/ISO 8601:1988 style numeric time zone (e.g., -0600 or +0100), or nothing if no time zone is determinable.
%Z The time zone abbreviation (empty if the time zone cannot be determined).
To be meaningful, the timestamp should always indicate at least day, month, year, hour, minutes
and second of the time of an event. Therefore, a meaningful timestamp format string necessarily
- at least one of %d, or %e to indicate day
- at least one of %b, %B, %m, or %h to indicate month
- at least one of %y or %Y to indicate year
- at least one of %H, %I, %k, %l to indicate hour
The timestamp format defined here also defines the timestamp format used within the PM data

description: The interval denotes the period in hours after which the configuration database is backed up
at the backup server again. The absolute time of the start of the period is relative to
The value 0 means disabled and indicates that the timer is not used.
That is, a periodic remote backup is never triggered.
variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemDbmBackupPeriod

description: Start time basis for remote DB backup after system restart, backup timer
The first backup will be started at this time + sheSystemDbmBackupPeriod and
will then be repeated each sheSystemDbmBackupPeriod.
Reminder: NE uses always a UTC time base.
variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemDbmBackupStartTime

description: Waiting period in minutes before next local backup, in case of configuration changes.
variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemDbmBackupWaitingPeriod

description: Maximum waiting period in minutes before next local backup, in case of configuration changes.
Because the DbmBackupWaitingPeriod is restarted with each new configuration command,
continuous configuration actions will prevent the system from storing these modifications into the flash.
The timer for DbmBackupWaitingPeriodMax will be started only once with the first config command
and force a data storing to the flash if it expire.
The feature can be disabled by using the value 0 as DbmBackupWaitingPeriodMax.
variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemDbmBackupWaitingPeriodMax

description: The remote backup waiting-time is the time in minutes after which the configuration database
is backed up at the backup server if it was latest altered by a configuration action.
The value of 0 means disabled and indicates that the timer is not used.
This does not influence the remote waiting-time-max parameter.
variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemDbmRemoteBackupWaitingPeriod

description: The remote backup waiting-time-max is the absolute time in minutes after which the configuration
database is backed up at the backup server if it was firstly altered by a configuration action.
The value of 0 means disabled and indicates that the timer is not used.
This does not influence the remote waiting-time parameter.
variables.name: SHE-SYSTEM-MIB::sheSystemDbmRemoteBackupWaitingPeriodMax

This path should be set relative to the ftp-server root.
Spaces in pathnames are not allowed, because of possible
problems with different FTP implementations (client and/or

It will be interpreted as an absolute path setting.
